abstract.para: Physics, chemistry, nutrients, primary productivity of lake N-2 from 1985- 1988

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: DATA FILE ENTERED BY: DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: Julie Pallant DATE: 8Oct91

para.literalLayout: Water, physics and chemistry sampled weekly from central station in N-2 on control and fertilized sides. Temperature and conductivity were read by the YSI model 33, conductivity meter. Dissolved O2 and Temperature were read by YSI model 57 oxygen meter, air calibrated. Surface and underwater light transmissiion were read using LICOR digital light meter. Carbonate alkalinity was titrated against pH depending on expected alkalinity (see Wetzel and Likens 1979). pH was measured electrometrically with a Corning portable expanded standard pH buffer and corrected for temperature of sample. A measure of carbon-12 available for algae for photosynthesis using pH, temperature of incubation, and carbonate alkalinity from alkalinity from tables in Wetzel and Likens (1979). Primary productivity measured by 14-CO2 uptake in 60 ml bottles incubated at depth collected ( 0,1,3,5,6-8m). Primary production was measured as mg 12C assimilated/m3-day from a 24 hour in situ incubation at central stations in N-2 calculated from 12 available and 14C added and assimilated by the algae measured as dpm corrected for quenching. 12-C available calculated from pH, temperature and carbonate alkalinity after the methods of Wetzel and Likens(Limnological Methods 1979, Saunders.) Soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) was measured with a non-extractive molybdate method reduced with ascorbic acid after (Strickland and Parson 1969 or Wetzel and Likens 1979). Color at 885 quantified with a Coleman single beam spectrophotometer (5cm light path), calibrated each run with external standard series to encompass the range of values anticipated (n=5 or 6 x duplicates/sample). Soluble ammonia in lake water was measured using a colorimetric test using phenate method (Wetzel and Likens 1979). NO2+NO3 is a measure of dissolved nitrate and nitrite in lake water from reduction of NO3 to nitrate followed by colorimetric development after method of Wetzel and Likens 1979.
Reference Citations: R.G. Wetzel & G.E. Likens. 1979. Limnological Methods. Saunders. Philadelphia.
